awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Methodology development for 3D atomic-scale structural dynamics movies of enzymes
awd_abstract_narration:
Capturing the dynamic structure of a biological machine performing its function remains the holy grail of biology. Conventional tools provide only structural "snapshots" of stable states along the reaction pathway. This project aims to develop methods that will capture a full movie of a macromolecule's structure as it works. The research tools developed will be applicable to a wide variety of biological systems, and will be disseminated by means of publications, tutorials, conference presentations and the like, to accelerate their adoption. The education component of the project will emphasize the use of single molecule biophysics and computational tools for dynamic structure determination. It will provide high school, undergraduate, graduate students and postdocs training in state-of-the-art single molecule biophysics research, and offer leadership experiences for graduate students and postdocs as well.

Specifically, this project will study the structure of the transcription bubble in a simple bacterial transcription system during initiation as a test case for developing new technological concepts. The existence of certain intermediates in bacterial transcription suggests common features of the process exist across the different domains of life and reflects a conserved regulatory mechanism; thus, the findings will have broad utility. For the purpose of dynamic structure determination, the project will combine experimental and theoretical tools, including multi-spot single-molecule FRET measurements, fast single-molecule microfluidic mixing, molecular dynamics simulations and time-resolved single-photon detection to acquire data on- and perform molecular modeling of- the transcription bubble during initiation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the funding periods, we prepared a library of fluorescently labeled E.coli σ70 variants to monitor conformational changes during the initial transition stages and the promoter escape process. Also, we developed a 48-spot single molecule FRET setup. Using this high-throughput multi-spot platform, we achieved single-molecule analysis of a given number of freely diffusing biological molecules ~40 times faster than the standard single-spot single-molecule FRET setup. We also successfully demonstrated real-time detection of molecules along the spots when combined with a simple linear flow system. The results of this work were summarized and published in Methods, 169, 21 (2019). Next, we designed a new 32-spot single-molecule analysis setup with alternating two-color line excitation. A PDMS-based microfluidic mixer system was designed to improve observation and mixing dead time by equipping it with a fast diffusive mixer and a serpentine-shaped observation channel. We found that the microfluidic mixer system could reduce the mixing dead time to milliseconds and increase the observation time up to one minute when applying ~1 mm/s flow rate. We also developed data analysis techniques and the establishment of experimental procedures and documentation for studying the dynamic structures of biomolecules using single-molecule FRET. In collaboration with several laboratories around the world, we investigated the reliability and accuracy of single-molecule FRET techniques and established single-molecule research procedures for studies characterizing the structural dynamics of biomolecules. These works were summarized in two publications: eLife, 10, e60416 (2021) and Nature Methods, 20, 523 (2023). Multi-parameter photon-by-photon hidden Markov modeling (mpH2MM) was developed to identify dynamic sub-populations and extract their kinetic information from single-molecule FRET measurements. The mpH2MM uses multiple observables for analysis, unlike the conventional single-parameter H2MM, which only uses photon streams related to proximity ratios in single molecule FRET measurements. This allows mpH2MM to decouple dye photophysics from FRET dynamics due to conformational changes in biomolecules. The results were published in Nature Communications, 13, 1000 (2021). We also developed a graphical user-friendly tool to convert many proprietary photon counting data files into open source Photon-HDF5 format. The work was summarized in Proceedings of SPIE. 11967,1196703 (2022). During the funding periods, we provided training in advanced molecular biology, cutting-edge in vitro structural studies using advanced single-molecule technologies, spectroscopy, and optics to 2 senior researchers, 2 postdocs, 3 graduate students, 5 undergraduate students, and 2 high school students.

The real-time observation of a highly dynamic transcription initiation intermediate of E. coli RNA polymerase may have a widespread impact due to the possibility that initiation intermediates could serve as a regulatory check-points and could be specifically inhibited and hence be targets for discovery of novel antibiotics. The elucidation of intermediates can shed more light on understanding how bacterial transcription is regulated and for developing new therapeutic strategies. New tools developed during this project could be useful for those who want to investigate the structure of other dynamic macromolecular systems that are too heterogeneous and dynamic to be characterized by other structural biology methods.
